message_1: What is the balanced redox reaction when copper metal reacts with silver nitrate solution to form copper (II) nitrate and silver metal?
message_2:
To balance the redox reaction between copper metal and silver nitrate solution, we first need to identify the oxidation and reduction half-reactions.

Oxidation half-reaction: Cu(s) → Cu²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻
Reduction half-reaction: Ag⁺(aq) + e⁻ → Ag(s)

Now, we need to balance the electrons in both half-reactions. Since the oxidation half-reaction has 2 electrons and the reduction half-reaction has 1 electron, we will multiply the reduction half-reaction by 2 to balance the electrons:

Oxidation half-reaction: Cu(s) → Cu²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻
Reduction half-reaction: 2Ag⁺(aq) + 2e⁻ → 2Ag(s)

Now, we can combine the two half-reactions to get the balanced redox reaction:

Cu(s) + 2Ag⁺(aq) → Cu²⁺(aq) + 2Ag(s)

Finally, we need to include the nitrate ions to complete the reaction:

Cu(s) + 2AgNO₃(aq) → Cu(NO₃)₂(aq) + 2Ag(s)

This is the balanced redox reaction for the reaction between copper metal and silver nitrate solution to form copper (II) nitrate and silver metal.
